snippet: Koji Uehara’s success this season as the closer for the Boston Red Sox adds weight to the argument that spending highly on that role is not always the best investment.
abstract: Tyler Kepner On Baseball column says that Koji Uehara’s success this season as the closer for the Boston Red Sox adds weight to the argument that spending highly on that role is not always the best investment; Uehara is in the first year of a two-year, $8.5 million contract that barely registered around baseball last winter, when teams again spent foolishly for saves.
lead_paragraph: Koji Uehara’s success this season as the closer for the Boston Red Sox adds weight to the argument that spending highly on that role is not always the best investment.

headline.main: The Closer: Not Quite as Important as You Think
headline.print_headline: The Closer: Not Quite as Important as You Think
